BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The deep wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Medium-sized and large avalanches are possible in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The deep wind slabs of the last few days can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Natural avalanches and stability tests have confirmed this situation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area snowfall. As a consequence of new snow and wind, further wind slabs will form. The wind slabs will form in all aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs of last week represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Down to low altitudes snow will fall on Friday. The more recent wind slabs will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise. In particular in the northwest and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.

Since Wednesday: The northwesterly wind has transported the fresh and old snow significantly. The sometimes deep wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant on steep north, east and south facing slopes above approximately 2000 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
Meticulous route selection is appropriate. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.
On very steep slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow, but less in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 2000 m.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. On wind-loaded slopes small and medium-sized avalanches were released.
The old snowpack is hard. Below approximately 1800 m thus far only a little snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Saturday: Northerly wind. The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Down to 1000 m and below snow will fall until the evening over a wide area. In the course of the day sometimes large wind slabs will form. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are in some cases large can be released easily.
The prevalence of these avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. Numerous medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. The new snow can be released naturally in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In these regions the previously small wind slabs will increase in size additionally until Sunday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Down to 1000 m and below snow will fall until the evening over a wide area. In the course of the day sometimes large wind slabs will form. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are in some cases large can be released easily.
The prevalence of these avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. Numerous medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. The new snow can be released naturally in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In these regions the previously small wind slabs will increase in size additionally until Sunday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Down to 1000 m and below snow will fall over a wide area. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase as the day progresses.
Since Sunday avalanche prone wind slabs formed in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation as well as at intermediate and high altitudes.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found also in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, and adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1000 m. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Faceted weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes. Backcountry touring calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In these regions the previously small wind slabs will increase in size additionally until Sunday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Down to 1000 m and below snow will fall over a wide area. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase as the day progresses.
Since Sunday avalanche prone wind slabs formed in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation as well as at intermediate and high altitudes.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found also in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, and adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1000 m. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Faceted weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes. Backcountry touring calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In these regions the previously small wind slabs will increase in size additionally until Sunday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area some new snow to low altitudes. In localities where more than 40 cm of snow falls danger level 3 (considerable) may be reached in the evening. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of the snowfall. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs that are forming during the snowfall represent the main danger. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. In isolated cases new snow is lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack. The snowpack will become gradually prone to triggering. In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area some new snow to low altitudes. In localities where more than 40 cm of snow falls danger level 3 (considerable) may be reached in the evening. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of the snowfall. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs that are forming during the snowfall represent the main danger. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. In isolated cases new snow is lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack. The snowpack will become gradually prone to triggering. In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Above approximately 900 m snow will fall over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be quite well bonded. The large quantity of fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs are bonding quite well with the old snowpack. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Above approximately 900 m snow will fall over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be quite well bonded. The large quantity of fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs are bonding quite well with the old snowpack. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: During the day: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Afternoon: The new snow represents the main danger. Can be released easily, or, in isolated cases, naturally in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes. As a consequence of snowfall and the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases above the tree line. At high altitude these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Caution is to be exercised in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Afternoon: Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The fresh wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in all aspects and above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: New snow and wind slabs require caution. The avalanche danger will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: During the day: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Afternoon: The new snow represents the main danger. Can be released easily, or, in isolated cases, naturally in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes. As a consequence of snowfall and the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases above the tree line. At high altitude these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Caution is to be exercised in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Afternoon: Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The fresh wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in all aspects and above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: New snow and wind slabs require caution. The avalanche danger will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Some snow will fall on Friday.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Down to low altitudes snow will fall on Friday.
Since Wednesday: In some localities mostly small wind slabs formed. They will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects.

The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases at their margins. Especially transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind, in particular on very steep slopes.
There is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 2000 m. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Saturday: Northerly wind. The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in high Alpine regions. At high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Over a wide area 5 to 10 cm of snow will fall on Friday above approximately 700 m.
In the evening as a consequence of the snowfall there will be a gradual increase in the avalanche danger. The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind, small wind slabs will form. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday above approximately 1500 m. Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the occasionally strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. These are prone to triggering at elevated altitudes. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. These avalanche prone locations are easy to recognise.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night. In isolated cases they are quite large. This applies in the regions with a lot of snow. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Friday: Evening and night: Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow will fall. The wind will be moderate to strong over a wide area. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes. The fresh wind slabs can in some cases be released easily.

The new snow is lying on a crust in all aspects below approximately 2600 m. Low and intermediate altitudes: The old snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. This also applies on steep sunny slopes at high altitude.

The old snowpack will be stable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow will fall until Sunday above approximately 1000 m. Slight increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind. Fresh wind slabs require caution.
A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
In some regions snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Medium-sized avalanches are possible in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Over a wide area sometimes deep wind slabs formed. The wind slabs of the last few days can be released.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence in particular in steep terrain.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Some snow will fall over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area some new snow to below approximately 1000 m. Isolated mostly small dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of the snowfall.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 15 to 25 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1500 m. Over a wide area from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust. These avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Some snow will fall over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area some new snow to below approximately 1000 m. Isolated mostly small dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of the snowfall.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 15 to 25 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1500 m. Over a wide area from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust. These avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. During the day:
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: During the day: The new snow represents the main danger. Can be released easily, or, in isolated cases, naturally in all aspects above the tree line. As a consequence of the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. At high altitude these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in shady places that are protected from the wind and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Caution is to be exercised in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Afternoon: Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The fresh wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in all aspects and above the tree line. At low altitude only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: New snow and wind slabs require caution. The avalanche danger will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. During the day:
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: During the day: The new snow represents the main danger. Can be released easily, or, in isolated cases, naturally in all aspects above the tree line. As a consequence of the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. At high altitude these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in shady places that are protected from the wind and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Caution is to be exercised in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Afternoon: Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The fresh wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in all aspects and above the tree line. At low altitude only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: New snow and wind slabs require caution. The avalanche danger will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.highlights: Above approximately 900 m snow will fall over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.highlights: Above approximately 900 m snow will fall over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Over a wide area from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The new snow can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be generally stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow will be deposited on a quite favourable old snowpack in all aspects.
The conditions are generally favourable. Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In some places small wind slabs formed. The fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases on steep shady slopes in high Alpine regions. The avalanche prone locations are rare and are easy to recognise.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 10 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1000 m. The strong wind has transported the new snow. The old snowpack will be stable over a wide area.

Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is wet all the way through and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs are to be bypassed as far as possible in high Alpine regions. At high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Over a wide area 5 to 10 cm of snow will fall above approximately 900 m. Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall. The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind, small wind slabs will form. Only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year in all altitude zones.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow will fall on Saturday above approximately 1300 m. Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall.
